fields.headline: Class notes
fields.bodyText: Expect this week to be a bit quieter on the education front. In fact, expect every week to pale in comparison with the last - school league tables, the promise of a revolution in 14-19 learning and the higher education white paper. All it needed was another secretary of state's resignation to cap it. But Charles Clarke shows no sign of an Estelle Morris-style confidence drain. Commentators at a briefing on the package for the universities last week were stunned by his performance. He spoke off the cuff for 40 minutes without hesitation, repetition or deviation - or notes. He'd be a wonder on Radio 4's Just a Minute ... Which is not to say Clarke is slip-free. You may have heard him on Jeremy Vine's Radio 2 show a couple of weeks ago, when he distinctly said: "I think we are pretty clear that we will be charging fees, unlike now, after university and so you pay through the tax system later on in your life." So that means the end of upfront tuition fees? Hold on, wait for the white paper, said his people, "there is not one iota of new ground that has been mapped out today". Except now we know we were right all along, and Clarke was inadvertently leaking his own policy. Just before Clarke unveiled the white paper, Tony Blair took prime minister's questions, with Clare Short and Gordon Brown, the biggest critics of top-up fees in the Cabinet, sitting either side of him. Not much support for Clarke when he made his statement either .... until praise for "a brave and bold policy" from Robert Jackson, Tory MP for Wantage and former higher education minister, who some of us remember as the chap charged with freezing the grant and introducing student loans in the 80s, the beginning of a line that led to last week's £3,000 fees. Ads are now appearing for a permanent head of the early years directorate of Ofsted - often dubbed OfTot - to succeed Maggie Smith, who left last year. Meanwhile, the new access regulator for higher education has been nicknamed OfToff ...
